questions.question: In a recent census survey conducted in a developing country, the government aims to measure the literacy levels among its population accurately. The survey team decides to calculate both the crude literacy rate and the effective literacy rate to gain a comprehensive understanding. What distinguishes the effective literacy rate from the crude literacy rate?

options.A: It provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups.
options.B: It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.
options.C: The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator.

questions.explanation: Rate focuses on the population aged 7 years and above . Crude Literacy Rate Effective Literacy Rate Definition : The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator. (Option C) Definition : The literacy rate is calculated using the population aged 7 years and above as the denominator. Includes the entire population. (Option D) Focuses on the population aged 7 years and above. Provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups. (Option A) Offers a more specific measure of literacy among individuals more likely to have completed basic education. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 560

questions.question: Which of the following topics was NOT included in the NFHS-5 conducted in 2019-21?

options.A: Blood pressure
options.B: Access to toilet facility
options.C: HIV status
options.D: Methods used for termination of pregnancy

questions.explanation: was the NFHS-5 in 2019-21, and the NFHS-6 (2023-24) is still being conducted. NFHS 5 was conducted by the International Institute for Population Sciences, Mumbai. Largest health survey system of India. Significance of NHFS Collects vital data on health and family welfare. Addresses government priorities. Captures emerging health and welfare concerns for policy development. Tracks health trends to assess intervention impacts. Identifies and addresses health disparities. Establishes baselines for future studies. Facilitates comparisons with global health standards. New topics included under NFHS-5 are: Disability Access to toilet facilities Death registration Menstrual hygiene Methods and reasons for abortion Hip and waist measurements Expansion of age range for measurement of Blood pressure level and blood glucose Note: HIV testing was excluded. Important parameters in NFHS-5 Parameter Value Sex ratio 1020; 929 at birth Total fertility rate 2.0 Effective literacy rate 84.4% Adult literacy rate 71.5% Anaemia in females (15-49 years) 67% Total dependency ratio 48.7 Reference: National Family Health Survey

questions.question: According to the system, which has the logo below and under the Central Birth and Death Registration Act, 1969, what is the time limit for registering for birth and death events in India?

options.A: 28 days
options.B: 21 days
options.C: 30 days

questions.explanation: Survey of the country) under the Central Births and Deaths Registration Act of 1969, which came into force on April 1st, 1970. The flame represents birth and the circle represents death. According to this system: Registration of birth and death is compulsory throughout the nation The public reports events occurring in their household, while heads of institutions, such as nursing homes, hotels, and jails, report events occurring in their institutes. The time limit for registering the event of birth and death in India is 21 days. For NRI, the time limit is 90 days. Default leads to a late fee. Since 2018, an Aadhaar number has been a must for registration for Death. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 968 About Us | Civil Registration System | Government of India

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding the Sample registration system?

options.A: An independent survey is conducted by an investigator-supervisor every 6 months.
options.B: Key data components of SRS are the number of births and death
options.C: An enumerator continuously keeps track of the birth and death count

questions.explanation: registration system was initiated in the mid-1960s. It is a dual record system. The enumerator continuously records the birth and death count. An Independent 6 monthly survey is conducted by a supervisor. It covers the entire nation, providing more reliable estimates of national birth and death rates and age-specific fertility and mortality rates. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 969 SAMPLE REGISTRATION SYSTEM (SRS)-BULLETIN 2020 VOLUME 55-I

questions.question: Which of the following data components are provided by the census? Population size and distribution HIV status and reproductive health status Education and employment status Nutritional status

options.A: 2, 3 and 4
options.B: 2 and 4
options.C: 1, 3 and 4

questions.explanation: compiling, and publishing demographic, economic, and social data about all individuals in a country at particular times. It started in 1881 and performed every 10-year interval; the latest census was in March 2011. Data components of the census are Population: Total count across states, districts, villages, and towns. Households: Number, size, and types (e.g., nuclear, joint families). Demographics: Age, gender, marital status, relationship to household head, migration. Economy: Employment status, income, industry. Education: Literacy rates, educational levels (primary, secondary, higher), and attendance. Housing: Type (rural, urban, slum), ownership, amenities (water, electricity), and conditions. Social: Religion, caste, tribe, languages spoken, and migration status. Health: Disability status, fertility rates (females). Geography: Administrative units (states, districts), rural/urban classification, and infrastructure details. HIV status and nutritional status are not included in the census. The National Family Health Surveys (NFHS) used to include HIV status in their surveys but have decided to exclude it in their latest survey. However, they continue to assess nutritional status in the NFHS. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 968 Census Division | Government of India .

questions.question: What does the De facto method of data collection refer to?

options.A: Information is collected only from a certain subset of the population.
options.B: Information is based on where people are found during the census.
options.C: Information is based on the individual's legal proof of permanent residency.
options.D: Information is only from institutional households.

questions.explanation: census. Explanation: The de facto method of data collection refers to gathering information based on the location where individuals are present at the time of the census or survey, regardless of their legal residency or registration status. De facto method De jure method Description This refers to collecting information based on the people's current location at the time of the survey. This method was used in the Indian Census only up to the 1930s This refers to the collection of information based on the individual's legal proof of permanent residency, regardless of where they stay during the survey. The Indian census survey currently uses this method. Example A legal resident of New Delhi may be living and working in Mumbai during the census; thus, if the de facto method is used, his data will be collected during the Mumbai census survey. A legal resident of New Delhi may be living and working in Mumbai during the census; thus, if the de jure method is used, his data will be collected during the New Delhi census survey. Reference: De facto vs. de jure enumerations

questions.question: Which of the following is also known as the final impact indicator in the National family planning program?

options.A: Total Fertility Rate (TFR)
options.B: Net Reproductive Rate (NRR)
options.C: Couples protection rate (CPR)

questions.explanation: final impact factor in the National family planning program. National Family Planning Program: For a country's population to stabilise, a TFR of 2.1 is required. It explains that every couple is giving birth to 2 children. TFR is the most important epidemiological indicator of family planning (Option A) For TFR to be 2.1, NRR (Net Reproductive Rate) must equal 1(Final impact indicator). (Option C) NRR equals 1 when the couple protection rate is >60%. The couple protection rate is >60% when females of reproductive age undergo sterilisation. (Option C) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg, 567

questions.question: Which of the following indicators helps to achieve the target of the national family planning program?

options.A: Age-specific fertility rate (ASFR)
options.B: Total fertility rate (TFR)
options.C: General fertility rate (GFR)

questions.explanation: operational indicator that helps to achieve the target of the national family planning program. It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples who are effectively protected against childbirth using approved family planning methods such as sterilisation, IUD, condoms, or oral pills. It is a grass root level indicator. Sterilisation represents over 60% of these protected couples. A Net Reproductive rate (NRR) of 1 can be achieved only if the CPR exceeds >60% Age-specific fertility rate (ASFR) (Option A) helps measure the changes in fertility over time in the same population. Still, more is needed to help achieve the target of the national family planning program. The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) (Option B) is the most important indicator in family planning. Still, achieving the national family planning program's target is less important than the couple protection rate. General fertility rate (GFR) (Option C) provides insight into the current fertility patterns and trends within a population, reflecting the overall fertility level regardless of age distribution. However, more is needed to achieve the target of the national family planning program. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 567 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9067234/

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the Net reproductive rate (NRR)? reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates

options.A: Indicator of complete family size
options.B: Defined as the no. of daughters or girls a newborn girl will bear or will have throughout her
options.C: The most sensitive indicator to evaluate the National family planning program

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Indicator of complete family size. Explanation: The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) indicates complete family size, not the Net reproductive rate. Net reproductive rate (NRR) Definition NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates. (Option B) Interpretation It is the most sensitive indicator to evaluate National family planning program (Option C) It is a mortality-dependent fertility indicator. (Option D) It is the best measure of growth of a population. Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she were to experience the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years). Total live births per 1000 women in a specific age group per year describe the A ge-Specific Fertility Rate (ASFR) . The average live births per 1000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) per year describe the G eneral Fertility Rate (GFR) . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 564 https://unstats.un.org/unsd/d emographic/products/dyb/DYBNat/NotesNatStatTab03.htm#:~:text=The%20net%20reproduction%20rate%20is,we re%20also%20subjected%20to%20the

questions.question: In a population, the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) are given for the following age groups: Age range Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) per 1000 women 15-19 years 80 45 20-24 years 280 120 25-29 years 220 110 30-34 years 170 90 35-39 years 85 45 40-44 years 21 10 45-49 years 3 2 Calculate the Gross Reproductive Rate (GRR) for the age group of 25 years.
questions.explanation: would have if she were to experience the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years). To calculate the gross reproductive rate (GRR), we need to consider only female births. The GRR is calculated by summing up the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) per 1000 women. Step 1: Sum the ASFR values of females. Total ASFR per 1000 women = 50 + 150 + 130 + 100 + 40 + 5 + 1 = 476 Step 2: Calculate the GRR. Formula : GRR for age group 25 years GRR for 25 age group= (25 X 476)/1000 = 11.9 GRR is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates of female live births across all age groups. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 564

questions.question: Which of the following best defines the total fertility rate (TFR)? life (15-49 years).

options.A: Total live births per 1000 women in a specific age group per year.
options.B: Average live births per 1000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) per year.
options.C: Average number of children per woman based on current fertility rates throughout her reproductive
options.D: Number of live births in a given year divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.

questions.explanation: throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years). reproductive life (15-49 years). Explanation: The Total Fertility rate (TFR) gives the average number of children a woman will have throughout her reproductive age group (15-49 years) . TFR indicates average family size. Family size is the number of children a woman has at a particular age within her reproductive years (15-49). Complete family size is the total number of children a woman has throughout her reproductive lifespan (until she is 49). TFR is best indicator of complete family size. TFR is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates across all age groups. If 5-year age groups are used, then the sum of rates is multiplied by Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she were to experience the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years). Net Reproductive Rate is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates. Total live births per 1000 women in a specific age group per year (Option A) describes the age-specific fertility rate (ASFR), not the total fertility rate. The average live births per 1000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) per year (Option B) describes the general fertility rate (GFR) but not the total fertility rate. The number of live births in a given year divided by the mid-year population multiplied by 1,000 (Option D) describes the crude birth rate (CBR), not the total fertility rate. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 564, 536.

questions.question: A health research team is studying fertility patterns in two neighbouring urban regions. The team decides to use the general and age-specific fertility rates for their analysis. Which approach will provide a more detailed understanding of fertility behaviour when comparing fertility patterns between the two regions?

options.A: Live births per 1000 women of childbearing age, 15-49 years
options.B: Live births per 1000 total population
options.C: Live births per 1000 women in specific age groups
options.D: Total number of births in the population

questions.explanation: fertility patterns between two neighbouring urban regions, age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) will provide a more detailed understanding of fertility behaviour than the general fertility rate (GFR). General Fertility rate Age-specific fertility rate (ASFR) Definition The total number of live births in an area in a year per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15- 44 or 49 years). (Option A) Number of live births in a year per 1000 women in any specific age group. (Option C) Disadvantages and advantages Disadvantage : Not everyone in the reproductive age group is exposed to the risk of childbirth Advantages : Unlike crude birth rate(CBR), ASFR is unaffected by differences, changes in population age composition It gives the fertility trends of a country. ASFR is more useful than GFR in comparing: Different populations Sub-groups of the same population. Measuring changes in fertility over time in the same population Live births per 1000 total population (Option B) represents the crude birth rate (CBR). Unlike CBR, ASFR is unaffected by differences and changes in population age composition. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 563 https://www.data4impactprojec t.org/prh/family-planning/fertility/age-specific-fertility-rates/#:~:text=Unlike%20the%20crude%20birth%20rate,in %20measuring%20changes%20over%20time.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines the crude birth rate?

options.A: Live births per 1,000 people in mid-year population per year
options.B: Live births per 1,000 people in annual population per year
options.C: Live births and stillbirths per 100,000 people in the mid-year population per year
options.D: Live births and stillbirths per 100,000 people in annual population per year

questions.explanation: birth rates Crude death rates Definition Number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year. Number of deaths (from all causes) per 1000 estimated mid-year population in one year in a given place. Statistics India’s current CBR is 19.5/1000 mid-year population. (2020) India’s current CDR is 6/1000 mid-year population. (2020) Drawbacks It gives a rough measure of fertility by giving birth rates, and not everyone in the population is exposed to childbirth. Lack of comparability across communities with different age, sex, race, etc. Note: The crude birth rate does not include stillbirths. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 563, 65 https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN?locations=IN https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CDRT.IN?locations=IN

questions.question: In the graph of a demographic transition model given below, identify the following.

options.A: A- Death rate, B- Population, C- Birth rate, X- Late expanding
options.B: A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Late expanding
options.C: A- Death rate, B- Birth rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding
options.D: A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding

questions.explanation: the demographic transition model, a country goes through 5 phases. Stages Birth rate Death rate Population High stationery High High Population is stable Early expanding High Starts declining Population grows at faster rate. Aka Demographic trap Late expanding Starts declining Keeps declining Population grows at slower rate (birth > death) Low stationery Low Low Stable population Declining Low Lower Population declines (death rate > birth rate)

questions.question: Which of the following is a positive mortality indicator?

options.A: Life expectancy
options.B: Infant mortality rate
options.C: Crude death rate

questions.explanation: indicators provide critical information about the health and well-being of a population. They are typically classified into positive and negative indicators based on the outcomes they represent. 1. Positive Mortality Indicators: These indicators generally suggest improvements in health and living conditions Life expectancy at birth: The average number of years a newborn is expected to live under current age-specific mortality rates. An increase in life expectancy implies improved health status and is a good indicator of overall socio-economic progress. It is important to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI). Recognised as a key measure of long-term survival and positive health outcomes worldwide. 2. Negative Mortality Indicators: These indicators usually reflect adverse health conditions or crises within a population: High Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) : Indicates poor perinatal care, malnutrition, and inadequate health services. (Option B) High Under-5 Mortality Rate: High rates signify poor living conditions, high birth rates, and high child mortality rates. (Option D) High Crude Death Rate (CDR): Reflects the general comparative health of the people and the rate at which people are dying. (Option C)

questions.question: A country has 40 million people under 15, 30 million aged 65 and over, and 150 million aged 15-64. What is the dependency ratio?
questions.explanation: dependent individuals per 100 economically productive individuals in a specific country, territory, or geographic area at a given time. To calculate the dependency ratio, we use the formula: No. of people under the age of 15 years = 40 million. No.of people above 65 years = 30 million. No. of people aged 15-65 years = 150 million. Calculation: (40+30)/150 x 100 = 70/150 x100 = 46.7% Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 559

questions.question: Which of the following are the implications of female deficit syndrome?

options.A: Increases maternal mortality.
options.B: Bias towards males in population counts.
options.C: Results in gender inequities.

questions.explanation: ratio, is the adverse sequel of gender inequality, gender preferences, and poor political legislation, which leads to an unstable population. Sex Ratio : Number of females per 1000 males. Importance in Demography : Crucial for understanding population dynamics. Influencing Factors : Mortality differences between genders. Sex-selective migration. Sex ratio at birth. Implications of Low Sex Ratio : Indicates a preference for male children. Results in gender inequities.(Option C) This leads to neglect of girls, higher female mortality in youth, female infanticide, and foeticide. Increases maternal mortality. (Option A) Bias towards males in population counts. (Option B) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 558

questions.question: Match the following terms and definitions with Terms Definitions 1. Demographic Burden a) Period of decrease in the dependency ratio 2. Demographic Bonus b) Indicates a rise in the total dependency ratio 3. Demographic Window c) Increase in economic growth rate 4. Demographic Dividend d) Peak working-age population phase
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c Explanation: Demographic Burden Refers to the increase in the proportion of the dependent population relative to the economically productive population. It signifies the societal challenge of supporting a larger dependent population, which typically occurs due to aging demographics. Demographic Bonus A phase in a nation's demographic evolution in which the proportion of the dependent population relative to the working-age population declines. This is often associated with economic growth opportunities as more people are in the workforce than dependents. Demographic Window: Refers to a period in a nation's demographic structure when the proportion of the population in the working-age group is at its highest. Demographic Dividend: An increase in economic growth driven by a growing proportion of working-age individuals in the population. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 559

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding demographic gifts?

options.A: It occurs when there is a significant increase in the working-age population.
options.B: It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals.
options.C: It leads to a demographic dividend for economic development.
options.D: It is associated with a decline in dependency ratios.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals Explanation: The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability. Demographic Gift Demographic Liability The demographic gift occurs when the working-age population is high relative to dependents. The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability. Represents a potential demographic dividend due to a larger workforce contributing to economic growth. Represents potential economic challenges due to increased dependency ratios and healthcare costs Contributors include higher productivity, increased savings, and economic growth Dependents include retirees, elderly individuals, and those requiring significant healthcare Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9395952/

questions.question: Population pyramid represents the age and sex composition of a population. All of the following statements about a Population Pyramid are false except?

options.A: A broad base and narrow apex indicate a high fertility rate and low life expectancy.
options.B: The width of the base of a population pyramid represents the elderly population.
options.C: They always have a symmetrical shape across all countries.
options.D: Population pyramids are static and do not change over time.

questions.explanation: expectancy. narrow apex indicates a lower proportion of elderly individuals (lower life expectancy). The population pyramid visually represents the age and gender distribution of a population. It displays age groups horizontally, with the youngest at the base and the oldest at the top, and divides the population by gender. (Option B) The pyramid forms a triangular shape when a population grows, indicating more births than deaths. This graphical representation allows for easy comparison between male and female populations within a region. It provides insights into the number of dependents and the overall demographic structure of the population at any given time. (Option D) The population pyramid is spindle-shaped in developed countries and triangular in developing countries. (Option C)

questions.question: Population and Vital statistics represent the demography of a population. Which of the following is not considered a vital statistic in demography?

options.A: Birth rate
options.B: Death rate
options.C: Life expectancy at birth

questions.explanation: of females per 1,000 males in a given population. The sex ratio, while important in demographic studies, is classified under population statistics (not vital statistics). Population statistics Vital statistics Population size Sex ratio Literacy rate Dependency ratio Population density Birth rate Death rate Natural growth rate Life expectancy at birth Mortality rate Fertility rate Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page. 556

questions.question: Assuming a population follows the Malthusian growth model and doubles in number in 20 years, what is its annual growth rate?
questions.explanation: that helps us calculate the time it takes for a population to double in number. It follows the rule of 70 : Time taken to double = 70 / Annual growth rate We know, Time = 20 years thus, Annual growth rate = 70/20 = 3.5 Annual growth rate = 3.5% Annual growth rate Doubling time If 1 % 70 years If 0.5 % 140 years If 2 % 35 years If 1.5 % 50 years Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 556

questions.question: Demographic transition refers to a change of demographic parameters like birth rate and death rate along with the dynamic process of socio- economic scenario. Which of the following scenarios best describes the demographic trap of a country? resources. population.

options.A: High birth rate (CBR) and declining death rate (CDR) lead to outpaced economic growth and
options.B: Declining birth rate (CBR), which falls below the death rate (CDR), thus leading to shrinkage of the
options.C: High birth rate (CBR) and high death rate (CDR) leading to a stable population without growth

questions.explanation: economic growth and resources. growth and resources. Explanation: A demographic trap refers to a country getting trapped in stage II (Early expanding) of the demographic transition model. With a high CBR and declining CDR, rapid population growth results, thus exceeding the country’s resources and economic growth. Declining CBR, which falls below the CDR, thus leading to population shrinkage (Option B) refers to Stage V (Declining) of the demographic transition. High CBR and CDR leading to a stable population without growth (Option C) refers to Stage I (High stationary) of the demographic transition. Most countries have already passed through this stage, and India was in this stage until 1920. Reference: The people yet to come; avoiding the demographic trap .

questions.question: Based on the demographic transition model, which transition phase does India belong to?

options.A: Early expanding
options.B: Late expanding
options.C: Low stationery

questions.explanation: III) of the demographic transition model as the birth rate is declining but at a slower pace than the death rate, which is also declining. Stage Countries I - High stationery India until 1920 II - Early expanding African and south Asian countries III - Late expanding India IV - Low stationary Austria, Denmark, Sweden V - Declining Germany, Italy, United Kingdom, Japan Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 554

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with the term demographic gap?

options.A: People entering and people leaving the country
options.B: Crude birth rate and crude death rate
options.C: Male population and female population
options.D: Age group of males and females

questions.explanation: rate, refers to the difference between a given population's crude birth rate and death rate This value excludes the migration of people into and out of the population. Demographic gap = Crude birth rate - Crude death rate Phases Demographic gap Explanation 1. High stationery Minimum Both birth and death rates are high, leading to minimal population growth. 2. Early expanding Maximum Death rates drop rapidly while birth rates remain high, causing a population explosion. 3. Late expanding Narrowing or Contracting Birth rates begin to decline and approach lower death rates, slowing population growth. 4. Low stationery Minimum Both birth and death rates are low and roughly equal, leading to a stable population size. 5. Declining Negative Birth rates fall below death rates, leading to population decline.
